title: The Virtue of Fasting Ramadhan
arabicText: مَنْ صَامَ رَمَضَانَ إِيمَانًا وَاحْتِسَابًا غُفِرَ لَهُ مَا تَقَدَّمَ مِنْ ذَنْبِهِ
transliteration: Man saama Ramadhana iimaanan wahtisaaban ghufira lahu ma taqaddama min dhanbih
translation: Whoever fasts Ramadhan out of faith and hoping for reward, his previous sins will be forgiven.
content: This hadith shows the immense reward of fasting with sincerity.
reflection: What is your intention for fasting this Ramadhan? Take a moment to renew your niyyah.

title: Night Prayer in Ramadhan
arabicText: مَنْ قَامَ رَمَضَانَ إِيمَانًا وَاحْتِسَابًا غُفِرَ لَهُ مَا تَقَدَّمَ مِنْ ذَنْبِهِ
transliteration: Man qaama Ramadhana iimaanan wahtisaaban ghufira lahu ma taqaddama min dhanbih
translation: Whoever stands (in prayer) during Ramadhan out of faith and hoping for reward, his previous sins will be forgiven.
content: Tarawih and Qiyam are unique opportunities in Ramadhan.
reflection: How do you feel when you stand before Allah in prayer at night?

title: Fasting is a Shield
arabicText: الصِّيَامُ جُنَّةٌ
transliteration: As-siyaamu junnah
translation: Fasting is a shield (from sins and from Hell).
content: Fasting protects the believer in both worlds.
reflection: Think of fasting not as deprivation, but as protection and purification.

title: The Reward of the Fasting Person
arabicText: لِلصَّائِمِ فَرْحَتَانِ: فَرْحَةٌ عِنْدَ فِطْرِهِ وَفَرْحَةٌ عِنْدَ لِقَاءِ رَبِّهِ
transliteration: Lis-saa'imi farhataan: farhatun 'inda fitrihi wa farhatun 'inda liqaa'i rabbih
translation: The fasting person has two joys: joy when breaking the fast and joy when meeting the Lord.
content: The happiness of iftar is a small taste of the joy of meeting Allah.
reflection: As you break your fast today, feel the gratitude and joy that comes with worship.

title: Gates of Paradise
arabicText: إِذَا دَخَلَ رَمَضَانُ فُتِّحَتْ أَبْوَابُ الْجَنَّةِ وَغُلِّقَتْ أَبْوَابُ النَّارِ وَصُفِّدَتِ الشَّيَاطِينُ
transliteration: Idha dakhala Ramadhanu futtihat abwaabul-jannah wa ghulliqat abwaabun-naar wa suffidatish-shayaateen
translation: When Ramadhan begins, the gates of Paradise are opened, the gates of Hell are closed, and the devils are chained.
content: Ramadhan is a month of unique divine mercy.
reflection: With the devils chained, any wrong we do is from our own nafs. Use this month to reform habits.

title: The Month of the Quran
arabicText: شَهْرُ رَمَضَانَ الَّذِي أُنزِلَ فِيهِ الْقُرْآنُ هُدًى لِّلنَّاسِ
transliteration: Shahru Ramadhana alladhii unzila fiihil Qur'aanu hudan lin naas
translation: The month of Ramadhan is that in which the Quran was revealed as guidance for the people.
content: This ayah establishes the intimate connection between Ramadhan and the Quran.
reflection: The Quran was sent down in this month for you. How will you engage with it today?

title: Fasting is Prescribed for You
arabicText: يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا كُتِبَ عَلَيْكُمُ الصِّيَامُ كَمَا كُتِبَ عَلَى الَّذِينَ مِن قَبْلِكُمْ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَتَّقُونَ
transliteration: Yaa ayyuhalladhiina aamanuu kutiba 'alaykumus-siyaamu kamaa kutiba 'alalladhiina min qablikum la'allakum tattaquun
translation: O you who believe, fasting has been prescribed for you as it was prescribed for those before you, that you may become righteous.
content: Fasting is a universal practice across divine religions.
reflection: The goal of fasting is taqwa (God-consciousness). Are you growing closer to that goal?

title: Allah is Near
arabicText: وَإِذَا سَأَلَكَ عِبَادِي عَنِّي فَإِنِّي قَرِيبٌ أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ إِذَا دَعَانِ
transliteration: Wa idhaa sa'alaka 'ibaadii 'annii fa innii qariib. Ujiibu da'watad-daa'i idhaa da'aan
translation: And when My servants ask you about Me — indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me.
content: This ayah appears immediately after the verses on fasting, emphasizing the power of du'a in Ramadhan.
reflection: Allah is near. Make du'a with certainty that He hears every whisper of your heart.

title: The Night of Decree
arabicText: لَيْلَةُ الْقَدْرِ خَيْرٌ مِّنْ أَلْفِ شَهْرٍ
transliteration: Laylatul-Qadri khayrun min alfi shahr
translation: The Night of Decree is better than a thousand months.
content: Laylatul Qadr falls in the last ten nights of Ramadhan.
reflection: One night of worship equals over 83 years. Are you prepared for the last ten nights?

title: Patience and Gratitude
arabicText: وَلَئِن شَكَرْتُمْ لَأَزِيدَنَّكُمْ
transliteration: Wa la'in shakartum la azeedannakum
translation: If you are grateful, I will surely increase you (in favor).
content: Gratitude is a key to abundance from Allah.
reflection: List three things you are grateful for today. Gratitude multiplies blessings.

title: Ar-Rahman — The Most Gracious
arabicText: ٱلرَّحْمَٰنُ
transliteration: Ar-Rahman
translation: The Most Gracious — whose mercy encompasses all of creation without exception.
content: Ar-Rahman is the Name that reflects Allah's all-encompassing mercy.
reflection: Reflect on one way Allah's mercy has shown up in your life today.

title: Ar-Raheem — The Most Merciful
arabicText: ٱلرَّحِيمُ
transliteration: Ar-Raheem
translation: The Most Merciful — who shows special mercy to the believers.
content: While Ar-Rahman is universal mercy, Ar-Raheem is mercy directed especially toward the faithful.
reflection: As a believer, know that Allah has a special mercy reserved for you. Seek it through worship.

title: Al-Ghaffar — The Oft-Forgiving
arabicText: ٱلْغَفَّارُ
transliteration: Al-Ghaffar
translation: The Oft-Forgiving — who repeatedly forgives sins.
content: No matter how many times we slip, Allah's forgiveness is available.
reflection: Ramadhan is the month of forgiveness. Turn to Al-Ghaffar with sincere repentance today.

title: As-Samee' — The All-Hearing
arabicText: ٱلسَّمِيعُ
transliteration: As-Samee'
translation: The All-Hearing — who hears every sound, every whisper, every thought.
content: Allah hears every du'a, every silent plea, every tear that falls.
reflection: Speak to Allah knowing He hears you. Your du'a is never lost.

title: Al-Kareem — The Most Generous
arabicText: ٱلْكَرِيمُ
transliteration: Al-Kareem
translation: The Most Generous — whose generosity knows no bounds.
content: Allah gives without being asked and even more when He is asked.
reflection: Be generous in Ramadhan as Allah is generous. Even a smile is charity.

title: The Prophet's Generosity in Ramadhan
content: Ibn Abbas reported that the Prophet ﷺ was the most generous of people, and he was most generous during Ramadhan when Jibreel would meet him. Jibreel used to meet him every night in Ramadhan to review the Quran. The Prophet ﷺ was more generous than the blowing wind.
reflection: The Prophet ﷺ increased in generosity during Ramadhan. What extra act of kindness can you do today?

title: Revelation Began in Ramadhan
content: The first verses of the Quran were revealed to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ in the Cave of Hira during Ramadhan. The angel Jibreel appeared and commanded: 'Read!' (Iqra'). This moment changed the course of human history forever.
reflection: The Quran first descended in Ramadhan. Honor this month by deepening your relationship with the Book of Allah.

title: The Battle of Badr
content: The decisive Battle of Badr took place on 17th Ramadhan, 2 AH. Despite being vastly outnumbered (313 vs 1000), the Muslims achieved a miraculous victory with divine aid. This battle established the Muslim community and proved that faith overcomes numbers.
reflection: Ramadhan is a month of victory — over enemies both external and internal. What inner battle will you win today?

title: I'tikaf in the Last Ten Nights
content: The Prophet ﷺ would perform i'tikaf (spiritual retreat in the mosque) during the last ten nights of Ramadhan, dedicating himself entirely to worship. He would stay in the mosque day and night, seeking Laylatul Qadr.
reflection: Even if you can't do full i'tikaf, dedicate extra time to worship in the last ten nights.

title: The Conquest of Makkah
content: The peaceful conquest of Makkah occurred on 20th Ramadhan, 8 AH. The Prophet ﷺ entered Makkah with 10,000 companions and granted a general amnesty to all its inhabitants, showing remarkable mercy and forgiveness.
reflection: The Prophet ﷺ conquered Makkah with mercy, not revenge. Is there someone you need to forgive this Ramadhan?

title: Ramadhan Means Scorching Heat
content: The word 'Ramadhan' comes from the Arabic root 'r-m-d' (رمض), which means intense heat or scorching. It was named so because it originally fell in the hot summer months, or because fasting burns away sins like intense heat burns the ground.
reflection: Let the 'heat' of fasting purify your soul and burn away bad habits.

title: 1.8 Billion Muslims Fast
content: Approximately 1.8 billion Muslims around the world observe Ramadhan. From the Arctic Circle where fasts can last 20+ hours to equatorial regions where fasts are around 12 hours, the whole ummah fasts together.
reflection: You are part of a global community of believers. Your worship connects you to Muslims everywhere.

title: The Quran was Completed in Ramadhan
content: In the final Ramadhan of the Prophet's ﷺ life, he reviewed the entire Quran twice with Jibreel. This established the tradition of completing the Quran during Ramadhan.
reflection: Even reading a few pages daily can help you connect deeply with the Quran this month.

title: Fasting Benefits the Body
content: Modern science has confirmed numerous health benefits of intermittent fasting, including improved insulin sensitivity, cellular repair (autophagy), reduced inflammation, and better heart health. The Prophet ﷺ recommended fasting 1400 years ago.
reflection: SubhanAllah — Allah prescribed fasting for spiritual growth, and it also heals the body.

title: The Night of a Thousand Months
content: Laylatul Qadr (the Night of Decree) is better than 1000 months — that's over 83 years of worship! It falls in the odd nights of the last ten days of Ramadhan. The Prophet ﷺ said to seek it in the last ten nights.
reflection: Don't miss the last ten nights. Even one night of sincere worship could equal a lifetime.

title: Du'a for Breaking Fast
arabicText: اللَّهُمَّ إِنِّي لَكَ صُمْتُ وَبِكَ آمَنْتُ وَعَلَيْكَ تَوَكَّلْتُ وَعَلَى رِزْقِكَ أَفْطَرْتُ
transliteration: Allahumma inni laka sumtu wa bika aamantu wa alayka tawakkaltu wa ala rizqika aftartu
translation: O Allah, for You I fasted, in You I believe, upon You I rely, and with Your provision I break my fast.
content: This du'a at iftar time is a moment of accepted supplication.
reflection: Say this du'a with full presence at the moment of Iftar — feel the weight of each word.

title: Du'a for Laylatul Qadr
arabicText: اللَّهُمَّ إِنَّكَ عَفُوٌّ تُحِبُّ الْعَفْوَ فَاعْفُ عَنِّي
transliteration: Allahumma innaka 'afuwwun tuhibbul 'afwa fa'fu 'anni
translation: O Allah, You are the Pardoner and You love to pardon, so pardon me.
content: Aisha (RA) asked the Prophet ﷺ what to say on Laylatul Qadr, and he taught her this profound du'a.
reflection: Memorize this du'a and repeat it often in the last ten nights.

title: Du'a Before Eating
arabicText: بِسْمِ اللَّهِ وَبَرَكَةِ اللَّهِ
transliteration: Bismillahi wa barakatillah
translation: In the name of Allah and with the blessing of Allah.
content: Begin every meal with bismillah for barakah.
reflection: Never underestimate the small du'as. They invite barakah into everything you do.

title: Du'a for Guidance
arabicText: رَبِّ اشْرَحْ لِي صَدْرِي وَيَسِّرْ لِي أَمْرِي
transliteration: Rabbi-shrah li sadri wa yassir li amri
translation: My Lord, expand for me my chest and ease for me my task.
content: Prophet Musa (AS) made this du'a before his great mission.
reflection: Ask Allah to open your heart and ease your path. He responds to those who call.

title: Du'a for Forgiveness
arabicText: أَسْتَغْفِرُ اللَّهَ الَّذِي لَا إِلَٰهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْحَيُّ الْقَيُّومُ وَأَتُوبُ إِلَيْهِ
transliteration: Astaghfirullahal-ladhi la ilaha illa huwal-hayyul-qayyumu wa atuubu ilayh
translation: I seek forgiveness from Allah, there is no god but He, the Living, the Self-Sustaining, and I repent to Him.
content: The Prophet ﷺ used to seek forgiveness more than 70 times a day.
reflection: Make istighfar a constant companion in your day, especially in Ramadhan.

title: The Purpose of Fasting
content: Fasting is not merely physical hunger. It is the hunger of the soul for nearness to Allah.
reflection: Let your fast be more than abstaining from food. Fast with your eyes, tongue, and heart.

title: Taqwa Through Fasting
content: The fast is a shield against the fire and protection from sins. So one who fasts should not be vulgar or argue.
reflection: Guard your fast from being nullified by bad speech and actions.

title: The Best of You
content: The best of you are those who learn the Quran and teach it.
reflection: In Ramadhan, commit to learning even one new surah and sharing knowledge with others.

title: Du'a is Worship
content: Du'a is the essence of worship. Nothing is more honored before Allah than du'a.
reflection: Never feel your du'a is too small or too big. Allah loves to be asked.

title: Charity Extinguishes Sin
content: Charity extinguishes sin as water extinguishes fire.
reflection: Even a small act of charity in Ramadhan carries immense reward. Give what you can today.
